theatre](/wiki/English_Renaissance_theatre "English Renaissance theatre"), the
role would have been played by a young boy, thus rendering any evocation of
the female form as ironic. Reading the play as a satire of gender roles, she
sees the speech as the culmination of this process.[130] Along similar lines,
Philippa Kelly says "the body of the boy actor in Shakespeare's time would
have created a sexual indeterminacy that would have undermined the patriarchal
narrative, so that the taming is only _apparently_ so. And in declaring
women's passivity so extensively and performing it centre-stage, Kate might be
seen to take on a kind of agency that rebukes the feminine codes of silence
and obedience which she so expressly advocates."[131] Similarly, Coppélia Kahn
argues the speech is really about how little Katherina has been tamed; "she
steals the scene from her husband, who has held the stage throughout the play,
and reveals that he has failed to tame her in the sense he set out to. He has
gained her outward compliance in the form of a public display, while her
spirit remains mischievously free."[138]

In relation to this interpretation, [William Empson](/wiki/William_Empson
"William Empson") suggests that Katherina was originally performed by an adult
male actor rather than a young boy. He argues that the play indicates on
several occasions that Katherina is physically strong, and even capable of
over-powering Petruchio. For example, this is demonstrated off-stage when the
horse falls on her as she is riding to Petruchio's home, and she is able to
lift it off herself, and later when she throws Petruchio off a servant he is
beating. Empson argues that the point is not that Katherina is, as a woman,
weak, but that she is not well cast in the role in life which she finds
herself having to play. The end of the play then offers blatant irony when a
strong male actor, dressed as a woman, lectures women on how to play their
parts.[139]

The fourth school of thought is that the play is a farce, and hence the speech
should not be read seriously or ironically. For example, Robert B. Heilman
argues that "the whole wager scene falls essentially within the realm of
farce: the responses are largely mechanical, as is their symmetry. Kate's
final long speech on the obligations and fitting style of wives we can think
of as a more or less automatic statement – that is, the kind appropriate to
farce – of a generally held doctrine."[140] He further makes his case by
positing:

> there are two arguments against [an ironic interpretation]. One is that a
> careful reading of the lines will show that most of them have to be taken
> literally; only the last seven or eight lines can be read with ironic
> overtones [...] The second is that some forty lines of straight irony would
> be too much to be borne; it would be inconsistent with the
> straightforwardness of most of the play, and it would really turn Kate back
> into a hidden shrew whose new technique was sarcastic indirection,
> sidemouthing at the audience, while her not very intelligent husband,
> bamboozled, cheered her on.[141]

Another way in which to read the speech (and the play) as farcical is to focus
on the Induction. H.J. Oliver, for example, emphasising the importance of the
Induction, writes "the play within the play has been presented only after all
the preliminaries have encouraged us to take it as a farce. We have been
warned."[111] Of Katherina's speech, he argues:

> this lecture by Kate on the wife's duty to submit is the only fitting climax
> _to the farce_ – and for that very reason it cannot logically be taken
> seriously, orthodox though the views expressed may be [...] attempting to
> take the last scene as a continuation of the realistic portrayal of
> character leads some modern producers to have it played as a kind of private
> joke between Petruchio and Kate – or even have Petruchio imply that by now
> he is thoroughly ashamed of himself. It does not, cannot, work. The play has
> changed key: it has modulated back from something like realistic social
> comedy to the other, 'broader' kind of entertainment that was foretold by
> the Induction.[133]

#### Gender
politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Taming_of_the_Shrew&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Gender politics")]

The issue of gender politics is an important theme in _The Taming of the
Shrew_. In a letter to the _[Pall Mall Gazette](/wiki/Pall_Mall_Gazette "Pall
Mall Gazette")_ , George Bernard Shaw famously called the play "one vile
insult to womanhood and manhood from the first word to the last."[142] A
contemporary critic, Emily Detmer, points out that in the late 16th and early
17th century, laws curtailing husbands' use of violence in disciplining their
wives were becoming more commonplace; "the same culture that still "felt good"
about dunking [scolds](/wiki/Common_scold "Common scold"), whipping whores, or
burning witches was becoming increasingly sensitive about husbands beating
their wives."[143] Detmer argues:

> the vigor of public discourse on wife-beating exemplifies a culture at work
> reformulating permissible and impermissible means for husbands to maintain
> control over the politics of the family, without, however, questioning that
> goal. This new boundary was built on notions of class and civil behaviour.
> Shakespeare's _The Taming of the Shrew_ acts as a comedic roadmap for
> reconfiguring these emergent modes of "skillful" and civilised dominance for
> _gentle_ men, that is, for subordinating a wife without resorting to the
> "common" man's brute strength.[144]

Petruchio's answer is to psychologically tame Katherina, a method not frowned
upon by society; "the play signals a shift towards a "modern" way of managing
the subordination of wives by legitimatising domination as long as it is not
physical."[145] Detmer argues "Shakespeare's "shrew" is tamed in a manner that
would have made the wife-beating reformers proud; Petruchio's taming "policy"
dramatises how abstention from physical violence works better. The play
encourages its audience not only to pay close attention to Petruchio's method
but also to judge and enjoy the method's permissibility because of the absence
of blows and the harmonious outcome."[146]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Tameing_a_Shrew%3B_or%2C_Petruchio%27s_Patent_Family_Bedstead%2C_Gags_%26_Thumscrews.png/150px-
Tameing_a_Shrew%3B_or%2C_Petruchio%27s_Patent_Family_Bedstead%2C_Gags_%26_Thumscrews.png)](/wiki/File:Tameing_a_Shrew;_or,_Petruchio%27s_Patent_Family_Bedstead,_Gags_%26_Thumscrews.png)

[](/wiki/File:Tameing_a_Shrew;_or,_Petruchio%27s_Patent_Family_Bedstead,_Gags_%26_Thumscrews.png
"Enlarge")

'Williams' cartoon from _Caricature_ magazine; "Tameing a Shrew; or,
Petruchio's Patent Family Bedstead, Gags & Thumscrews" (1815).

However, Detmer is critical of scholars who defend Shakespeare for depicting
male dominance in a less brutal fashion than many of his contemporaries. For
example, although not specifically mentioned by Detmer, Michael West writes
"the play's attitude was characteristically Elizabethan and was expressed more
humanly by Shakespeare than by some of his sources."[147] Detmer goes on to
read the play in light of modern psychological theories regarding women's
responses to [domestic violence](/wiki/Domestic_violence "Domestic violence"),
and argues that Katherina develops [Stockholm
syndrome](/wiki/Stockholm_syndrome "Stockholm syndrome"):

> a model of domestic violence that includes tactics other than physical
> violence gives readers a way in which to understand Kate's romanticised
> surrender at the end of the play as something other than consensual, as, in
> fact, a typical response to abuse [...] Like a victim of the Stockholm
> syndrome, she denies her own feelings in order to bond with her abuser. Her
> surrender and obedience signify her emotional bondage as a survival
> strategy; she aims to please because her life depends upon it. Knowing how
> the Stockholm syndrome works can help us to see that whatever
> "[subjectivity](/wiki/Subjectivity "Subjectivity")" might be achieved is
> created out of domination and a coercive bonding.[148]

In a [Marxist](/wiki/Marxist_literary_criticism "Marxist literary criticism")
reading of the play, Natasha Korda argues that, although Petruchio is not
characterised as a violent man, he still embodies sixteenth century notions
regarding the subjugation and objectification of women. Shrew taming stories
existed prior to Shakespeare's play, and in such stories, "the object of the
tale was simply to put the shrew to work, to restore her (frequently through
some gruesome form of punishment) to her proper productive place within the
household economy."[149] Petruchio does not do this, but Korda argues he still
works to curtail the activities of the woman; "Kate [is] not a reluctant
producer, but rather an avid and sophisticated consumer of market goods [...]
Petruchio's taming strategy is accordingly aimed not at his wife's productive
capacity – not once does he ask Kate to brew, bake, wash, card, or spin – but
at her consumption. He seeks to educate her in her role as a consumer."[150]
She believes that even though Petruchio does not use force to tame Katherina,
his actions are still an endorsement of patriarchy; he makes her his property
and tames her into accepting a patriarchal economic worldview. Vital in this
reading is Katherina's final speech, which Korda argues "inaugurates a new
gendered division of labour, according to which husbands "labour both by sea
and land" while their wives luxuriate at home [...] In erasing the status of
[housework](/wiki/Homemaking "Homemaking") as work, separate-sphere ideology
renders the [housewife](/wiki/Housewife "Housewife") perpetually indebted to
her husband [...] _The Taming of the Shrew_ marks the emergence of the
ideological separation of feminine and masculine spheres of labour."[151]

In a different reading of how gender politics are handled in the play, David
Beauregard reads the relationship between Katherina and Petruchio in
traditional [Aristotelian](/wiki/Aristotelianism "Aristotelianism") terms.
Petruchio, as the architect of [virtue](/wiki/Virtue "Virtue")
(_[Politics](/wiki/Politics_\(Aristotle\) "Politics \(Aristotle\)")_ , 1.13),
brings Kate into harmony with her nature by developing her "new-built virtue
and obedience", (5.2.118), and she, in turn, brings to Petruchio in her person
all the Aristotelian components of happiness – wealth and good fortune,
virtue, friendship and love, the promise of domestic peace and quiet
(_[Nicomachean Ethics](/wiki/Nicomachean_Ethics "Nicomachean Ethics")_ ,
1.7–8). The virtue of obedience at the center of Kate's final speech is not
what Aristotle describes as the despotic rule of master over slave, but rather
the statesman's rule over a free and equal person (_Politics_ , 1.3, 12–13).
Recognising the evil of despotic domination, the play holds up in inverse form
Kate's shrewishness, the feminine form of the will to dominance, as an evil
that obstructs natural fulfillment and destroys marital happiness.[152]

####
Cruelty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Taming_of_the_Shrew&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Cruelty")]

Another theme in the play is cruelty. Alexander Leggatt states:

> the taming of Katherina is not just a lesson, but a game – a test of skill
> and a source of pleasure. The roughness is, at bottom, part of the fun: such
> is the peculiar psychology of sport that one is willing to endure aching
> muscles and risk the occasional broken limb for the sake of the challenge.
> The sports most often recalled throughout the play are [blood
> sports](/wiki/Blood_sport "Blood sport"), hunting and
> [hawking](/wiki/Falconry "Falconry"), thus invoking in the audience the
> state of mind in which cruelty and violence are acceptable, even exciting,
> because their scope is limited by tacit agreement and they are made the
> occasion for a display of skill.[153]

Ann Thompson argues that "the fact that in the folktale versions the shrew-
taming story always comes to its climax when the husbands wager on their
wives' obedience must have been partly responsible for the large number of
references to sporting, gaming and gambling throughout the play. These
metaphors can help to make Petruchio's cruelty acceptable by making it seem
limited and conventionalised."[154] Marvin Bennet Krims argues that "the play
leans heavily on representations of cruelty for its comedic effect."[155] He
believes cruelty permeates the entire play, including the Induction, arguing
the Sly frame, with the Lord's spiteful practical joke, prepares the audience
for a play willing to treat cruelty as a comedic matter.[156] He suggests that
cruelty is a more important theme than gender, arguing that "the aggression
represented in _Taming_ can be read as having less to do with gender and more
to do with hate, with the text thereby becoming a comic representation of the
general problem of human cruelty and victimisation."[157]

Director [Michael Bogdanov](/wiki/Michael_Bogdanov "Michael Bogdanov"), who
directed the play in 1978, considers that "Shakespeare was a feminist":

> Shakespeare shows women totally abused – like animals – bartered to the
> highest bidder. He shows women used as commodities, not allowed to choose
> for themselves. In _The Taming of the Shrew_ you get that extraordinary
> scene between Baptista, Grumio, and Tranio, where they are vying with each
> other to see who can offer most for Bianca, who is described as 'the prize'.
> It is a toss of the coin to see which way she will go: to the old man with a
> certain amount of money, or to the young man, who is boasting that he's got
> so many ships. She could end up with the old impotent fool, or the young
> 'eligible' man: what sort of life is that to look forward to? There is no
> question of it, [Shakespeare's] sympathy is with the women, and his purpose,
> to expose the cruelty of a society that allows these things to happen.[158]

####
Money[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Taming_of_the_Shrew&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Money")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/John_Drew_as_Petruchio.jpg/150px-
John_Drew_as_Petruchio.jpg)](/wiki/File:John_Drew_as_Petruchio.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:John_Drew_as_Petruchio.jpg "Enlarge")

[John Drew](/wiki/John_Drew,_Jr. "John Drew, Jr.") as Petruchio in [Augustin
Daly](/wiki/Augustin_Daly "Augustin Daly")'s 1887 production at Daly's
Theatre, New York.

The motivation of money is another theme. When speaking of whether or not
someone may ever want to marry Katherina, Hortensio says "Though it pass your
patience and mine to endure her loud alarums, why man, there be good fellows
in the world, and a man could light on them, would take her with all faults
and money enough" (1.1.125–128). In the scene that follows Petruchio says:

> If thou know  
>  One rich enough to be Petruchio's wife-  
>  As wealth is burden of my wooing dance-  
>  Be she as foul as was [Florentius](/wiki/Confessio_Amantis#The_tales
> "Confessio Amantis")' love,  
>  As old as
> [Sibyl](/wiki/Cumaean_Sibyl#Stories_recounted_in_Ovid's_Metamorphoses
> "Cumaean Sibyl"), and as curst and shrewd  
>  As Socrates' Xanthippe, or a worse,  
>  She moves me not.  
>  (1.2.65–71)

A few lines later Grumio says, "Why give him gold enough and marry him to a
puppet or an [aglet](/wiki/Aglet "Aglet")-baby, or an old trot with ne're a
tooth in her head, though she have as many diseases as two and fifty horses.
Why, nothing comes amiss, so money comes withal" (1.2.77–80). Furthermore,
Petruchio is encouraged to woo Katherina by Gremio, Tranio (as Lucentio), and
Hortensio, who vow to pay him if he wins her, on top of Baptista's dowry
("After my death, the one half of my lands, and in possession, twenty thousand
crowns"). Later, Petruchio does not agree with Baptista on the subject of love
in this exchange:

> _BAPTISTA_  
>  When the special thing is well obtained,  
>  That is, her love; for that is all in all.  
>  
>  _PETRUCHIO_  
>  Why that is nothing.  
>  (2.1.27–29)

Gremio and Tranio literally bid for Bianca. As Baptista says, "'Tis deeds must
win the prize, and he of both/That can assure my daughter greatest dower/Shall
have my Bianca's love" (2.1.344–346).

###
Opera[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Taming_of_the_Shrew&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Opera")]

The first opera based on the play was [Ferdinando
Bertoni](/wiki/Ferdinando_Bertoni "Ferdinando Bertoni")'s [opera
buffa](/wiki/Opera_buffa "Opera buffa") _Il duca di Atene_ (1780), with
[libretto](/wiki/Libretto "Libretto") by Carlo Francesco Badini.[159]

[Frederic Reynolds](/wiki/Frederic_Reynolds "Frederic Reynolds")' _Catherine
and Petruchio_ (1828) is an adaptation of Garrick, with an
[overture](/wiki/Overture "Overture") taken from [Gioachino
Rossini](/wiki/Gioachino_Rossini "Gioachino Rossini"), songs derived from
numerous Shakespeare plays and [sonnets](/wiki/Shakespeare%27s_sonnets
"Shakespeare's sonnets"), and music by [John Braham](/wiki/John_Braham "John
Braham") and [Thomas Simpson Cooke](/wiki/Thomas_Simpson_Cooke "Thomas Simpson
Cooke").[160] Starring [Fanny Ayton](/wiki/Fanny_Ayton "Fanny Ayton") and
[James William Wallack](/wiki/James_William_Wallack "James William Wallack"),
the opera premiered at Drury Lane, but it was not successful, and closed after
only a few performances.[161] [Hermann Goetz](/wiki/Hermann_Goetz "Hermann
Goetz")' _[Der Widerspänstigen
Zähmung](/wiki/Der_Widersp%C3%A4nstigen_Z%C3%A4hmung "Der Widerspänstigen
Zähmung")_ (1874), with libretto by Joseph Viktor Widmann, is a [comic
opera](/wiki/Comic_opera "Comic opera"), which focuses on the Bianca subplot,
and cuts back the taming story. It was first performed at the original
[National Theatre Mannheim](/wiki/National_Theatre_Mannheim "National Theatre
Mannheim").[162] [John Kendrick Bangs](/wiki/John_Kendrick_Bangs "John
Kendrick Bangs")' _Katherine: A Travesty_ (1888) is a [Gilbert and
Sullivan](/wiki/Gilbert_and_Sullivan "Gilbert and Sullivan")-style parody
[operetta](/wiki/Operetta "Operetta") which premiered in the [Metropolitan
Opera](/wiki/Metropolitan_Opera "Metropolitan Opera").[163] [Spyridon
Samaras](/wiki/Spyridon_Samaras "Spyridon Samaras")' _La furia domata:
commedia musicale in tre atti_ (1895) is a now lost lyric comedy with libretto
by Enrico Annibale Butti and Giulio Macchi, which premiered at the [Teatro
Lirico](/wiki/Teatro_Lirico_\(Milan\) "Teatro Lirico \(Milan\)").[164]
[Ruperto Chapí](/wiki/Ruperto_Chap%C3%AD "Ruperto Chapí")'s _[Las
bravías](/wiki/Las_brav%C3%ADas "Las bravías")_ (1896), with a libretto by
[José López Silva](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_L%C3%B3pez_Silva "José López Silva") and
[Carlos Fernández Shaw](/wiki/Carlos_Fern%C3%A1ndez_Shaw "Carlos Fernández
Shaw"), is a one-act _[género chico](/wiki/G%C3%A9nero_chico "Género chico")_
_[zarzuela](/wiki/Zarzuela "Zarzuela")_ clearly based on the story, but with
names changed and the location altered to Madrid: it was a major success in
Spain, with over 200 performances in 1896 alone, and continues to be performed
regularly.[165]

[Johan Wagenaar](/wiki/Johan_Wagenaar "Johan Wagenaar")'s _De getemde feeks_
(1909) is the second of three overtures Wagenaar wrote based on Shakespeare,
the others being _Koning Jan_ (1891) and _Driekoningenavond_ (1928).[166]
Another overture inspired by the play is [Alfred
Reynolds](/wiki/Alfred_Reynolds_\(composer\) "Alfred Reynolds \(composer\)")'
_The Taming of the Shrew Overture_ (1927).[167] [Ermanno Wolf-
Ferrari](/wiki/Ermanno_Wolf-Ferrari "Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari")'s
[verismo](/wiki/Verismo_\(music\) "Verismo \(music\)") opera _[Sly, ovvero la
leggenda del dormiente risvegliato](/wiki/Sly_\(opera\) "Sly \(opera\)")_
(1927) focuses on the Induction, with libretto by [Giovacchino
Forzano](/wiki/Giovacchino_Forzano "Giovacchino Forzano"). A tragedy, the
opera depicts Sly as a hard-drinking and debt-ridden poet who sings in a
London pub. When he is tricked into believing that he is a lord, his life
improves, but upon learning it is a ruse, he mistakenly concludes the woman he
loves (Dolly) only told him she loved him as part of the ruse. In despair, he
kills himself by cutting his wrists, with Dolly arriving too late to save him.
Starring [Aureliano Pertile](/wiki/Aureliano_Pertile "Aureliano Pertile") and
[Mercedes Llopart](/wiki/Mercedes_Llopart "Mercedes Llopart"), it was first
performed at [La Scala](/wiki/La_Scala "La Scala") in Milan.[168] [Rudolf
Karel](/wiki/Rudolf_Karel "Rudolf Karel")'s _The Taming of the Shrew_ is an
unfinished opera upon which he worked between 1942 and 1944.[164] [Philip
Greeley Clapp](/wiki/Philip_Greeley_Clapp "Philip Greeley Clapp")'s _The
Taming of the Shrew_ (1948) was first performed at the Metropolitan
Opera.[169] [Vittorio Giannini](/wiki/Vittorio_Giannini "Vittorio Giannini")'s
_[The Taming of the Shrew](/wiki/The_Taming_of_the_Shrew_\(Giannini\) "The
Taming of the Shrew \(Giannini\)")_ (1953) is an opera buffa, with libretto by
Giannini and Dorothy Fee. It was first performed at the [Cincinnati Music
Hall](/wiki/Music_Hall_\(Cincinnati\) "Music Hall \(Cincinnati\)"), starring
[Dorothy Short](/wiki/Dorothy_Short "Dorothy Short") and Robert Kircher.[169]
[Vissarion Shebalin](/wiki/Vissarion_Shebalin "Vissarion Shebalin")'s
_[Ukroshchenye stroptivoy](/wiki/The_Taming_of_the_Shrew_\(Shebalin\) "The
Taming of the Shrew \(Shebalin\)")_ (1957), with libretto by Abram Akimovich
Gozenpud, was Shebalin's last opera and was immediately hailed as a
masterpiece throughout Russia.[170] [Dominick Argento](/wiki/Dominick_Argento
"Dominick Argento")'s _[Christopher Sly](/wiki/Christopher_Sly_\(opera\)
"Christopher Sly \(opera\)")_ (1962), with libretto by John Manlove, is a
comic opera in two scenes and an [interlude](/wiki/Entr%27acte "Entr'acte"),
first performed in the [University of Minnesota](/wiki/University_of_Minnesota
"University of Minnesota"). Sly is duped by a Lord into believing that he
himself is a lord. However, he soon becomes aware of the ruse, and when left
alone, he flees with the Lord's valuables and his two mistresses.[171]

###
Musical/Ballet[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Taming_of_the_Shrew&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Musical/Ballet")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Katherine_hits_the_music_master.jpg/220px-
Katherine_hits_the_music_master.jpg)](/wiki/File:Katherine_hits_the_music_master.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Katherine_hits_the_music_master.jpg "Enlarge")

[Louis Rhead](/wiki/Louis_Rhead "Louis Rhead") ink drawing of Katherine
breaking a lute over Hortensio's head, designed for a 1918 edition of _[Tales
from Shakespeare](/wiki/Tales_from_Shakespeare "Tales from Shakespeare")_.

The earliest known [musical](/wiki/Musical_theatre "Musical theatre")
adaptation of the play was a [ballad opera](/wiki/Ballad_opera "Ballad opera")
based on Charles Johnson's _Cobler of Preston_. Called _The Cobler of Preston
's Opera_, the piece was anonymously written, although [William
Dunkin](/wiki/William_Dunkin "William Dunkin") is thought by some scholars as
a likely candidate. Rehearsals for the premier began in [Smock
Alley](/wiki/Smock_Alley_Theatre "Smock Alley Theatre") in October 1731, but
sometime in November or December, the show was cancelled. It was instead
performed by a group of children (including an eleven-year-old [Peg
Woffington](/wiki/Peg_Woffington "Peg Woffington")) in January 1732 at Signora
Violante's New Booth in [Dame Street](/wiki/Dame_Street "Dame Street"). It was
subsequently published in March.[172]

[James Worsdale](/wiki/James_Worsdale "James Worsdale")'s _A Cure for a Scold_
is also a ballad opera. First performed at Drury Lane in 1735, starring [Kitty
Clive](/wiki/Kitty_Clive "Kitty Clive") and [Charles
Macklin](/wiki/Charles_Macklin "Charles Macklin"), _A Cure for a Scold_ was an
adaptation of Lacy's _Sauny the Scot_ rather than Shakespeare's original
_Taming of the Shrew_.[173] Petruchio was renamed Manly, and Katherina was
renamed Margaret (nicknamed Peg). At the end, there is no wager. Instead, Peg
pretends she is dying, and as Petruchio runs for a doctor, she reveals she is
fine, and declares "you have taught me what 'tis to be a Wife, and I shall
make it my Study to be obliging and obedient," to which Manly replies "My best
Peg, we will exchange Kindness, and be each others Servants." After the play
has finished, the actress playing Peg steps forward and speaks directly to the
audience as herself; "Well, I must own, it wounds me to the Heart/To play,
unwomanly, so mean a Part./What – to submit, so tamely – so contented,/Thank
Heav'n! I'm not the Thing I represented."[174]

Cole Porter's musical _[Kiss Me, Kate](/wiki/Kiss_Me,_Kate "Kiss Me, Kate")_
is an adaptation of _Taming of the Shrew_. The music and lyrics are by Porter
and the [book](/wiki/Musical_theatre#Book_musicals "Musical theatre") is by
[Samuel and Bella Spewack](/wiki/Samuel_and_Bella_Spewack "Samuel and Bella
Spewack"). It is at least partially based on the 1935/1936 Theatre Guild
production of _Taming of the Shrew_ , which starred husband and wife Alfred
Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, whose backstage fights became legendary. The musical
tells the story of a husband and wife acting duo (Fred and Lilli) attempting
to stage _The Taming of the Shrew_ , but whose backstage fights keep getting
in the way.[175][176] The musical opened on Broadway at the [New Century
Theatre](/wiki/New_Century_Theatre "New Century Theatre") in 1948, running for
a total of 1,077 performances. Directed by [John C.
Wilson](/wiki/John_C._Wilson "John C. Wilson") with choreography by [Hanya
Holm](/wiki/Hanya_Holm "Hanya Holm"), it starred [Patricia
Morison](/wiki/Patricia_Morison "Patricia Morison") and [Alfred
Drake](/wiki/Alfred_Drake "Alfred Drake").[177] The production moved to the
[West End](/wiki/West_End_theatre "West End theatre") in 1951, directed by
Samuel Spewack with choreography again by Holm, and starring Patricia Morrison
and [Bill Johnson](/wiki/Bill_Johnson_\(musical_theatre_actor\) "Bill Johnson
\(musical theatre actor\)"). It ran for 501 performances.[177] As well as
being a box office hit, the musical was also a critical success, winning five
[Tony Awards](/wiki/Tony_Award "Tony Award"); [Best Authors
(Musical)](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Author "Tony Award for Best Author"),
[Best Original Score](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Tony Award for
Best Original Score"), [Best Costume
Design](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Costume_Design "Tony Award for Best Costume
Design"), [Best Musical](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Musical "Tony Award for
Best Musical") and Best Producers (Musical).[178] The play has since been
revived numerous times in various countries. Its 1999 revival at the [Martin
Beck Theatre](/wiki/Al_Hirschfeld_Theatre "Al Hirschfeld Theatre"), directed
by [Michael Blakemore](/wiki/Michael_Blakemore "Michael Blakemore") and
starring [Marin Mazzie](/wiki/Marin_Mazzie "Marin Mazzie") and [Brian Stokes
Mitchell](/wiki/Brian_Stokes_Mitchell "Brian Stokes Mitchell"), was especially
successful, winning another five Tonys; [Best Actor
(Musical)](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Musical "Tony Award for Best
Actor in a Musical"), Best Costume Design, [Best Director
(Musical)](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Direction_of_a_Musical "Tony Award for
Best Direction of a Musical"), [Best
Orchestrations](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Orchestrations "Tony Award for Best
Orchestrations"), and [Best Revival
(Musical)](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Revival_of_a_Musical "Tony Award for Best
Revival of a Musical").[179]

The first [ballet](/wiki/Ballet "Ballet") version of the play was [Maurice
Béjart](/wiki/Maurice_B%C3%A9jart "Maurice Béjart")'s _La mégère apprivoisée_.
Using the music of [Alessandro Scarlatti](/wiki/Alessandro_Scarlatti
"Alessandro Scarlatti"), it was originally performed by the [Ballet de l'Opéra
de Paris](/wiki/Paris_Opera_Ballet "Paris Opera Ballet") in 1954.[180] The
best known ballet adaptation is [John Cranko](/wiki/John_Cranko "John
Cranko")'s _[The Taming of the Shrew](/wiki/The_Taming_of_the_Shrew_\(ballet\)
"The Taming of the Shrew \(ballet\)")_ , first performed by the [Stuttgart
Ballet](/wiki/Stuttgart_Ballet "Stuttgart Ballet") at the [Staatsoper
Stuttgart](/wiki/Staatsoper_Stuttgart "Staatsoper Stuttgart") in 1969.[164]
Another ballet adaptation is [Louis Falco](/wiki/Louis_Falco "Louis Falco")'s
_Kate 's Rag_, first performed by the Louis Falco Dance Company at the
[Akademie der Künste](/wiki/Academy_of_Arts,_Berlin "Academy of Arts, Berlin")
in 1980.[181] In 1988, [Aleksandre Machavariani](/wiki/Aleksandre_Machavariani
"Aleksandre Machavariani") composed a ballet suite, but it was not performed
until 2009, when his son, [conductor](/wiki/Conducting "Conducting") Vakhtang
Machavariani, gave a concert at the Georgian National Music Center featuring
music by [Modest Mussorgsky](/wiki/Modest_Mussorgsky "Modest Mussorgsky"),
[Sergei Prokofiev](/wiki/Sergei_Prokofiev "Sergei Prokofiev") and some of his
father's pieces.[182]

###
Radio[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Taming_of_the_Shrew&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Radio")]

In 1924, extracts from the play were broadcast on [BBC Radio](/wiki/BBC_Radio
"BBC Radio"), performed by the Cardiff Station Repertory Company as the eight
episode of a series of programs showcasing Shakespeare's plays, entitled
_Shakespeare Night_.[183] Extracts were also broadcast in 1925 as part of
_Shakespeare: Scene and Story_ , with Edna Godfrey-Turner and [William Charles
Macready](/wiki/William_Macready "William Macready"),[184] and in 1926 as part
of _Shakespeare 's Heroines_, with [Madge Titheradge](/wiki/Madge_Titheradge
"Madge Titheradge") and [Edmund Willard](/wiki/Edmund_Willard "Edmund
Willard").[185] In 1927, a forty-three-minute truncation of the play was
broadcast on [BBC National Programme](/wiki/BBC_National_Programme "BBC
National Programme"), with [Barbara Couper](/wiki/Barbara_Couper "Barbara
Couper") and [Ian Fleming](/wiki/Ian_Fleming_\(actor\) "Ian Fleming
\(actor\)").[186] In 1932, National Programme aired another truncated version,
this one running eighty-five minutes, and again starring Couper, with Francis
James as Petruchio.[187] In 1935, Peter Creswell directed a broadcast of the
relatively complete text (only the Bianca subplot was trimmed) on National
Programme, starring Mary Hinton and [Godfrey Tearle](/wiki/Godfrey_Tearle
"Godfrey Tearle").[188] This was the first non-theatrical version of the play
to feature Sly, who was played by Stuart Robertson.[189] In 1941, Creswell
directed another adaptation for [BBC Home Service](/wiki/BBC_Home_Service "BBC
Home Service"), again starring Tearle, with [Fay Compton](/wiki/Fay_Compton
"Fay Compton") as Katherina.[190] In 1947, [BBC Light
Programme](/wiki/BBC_Light_Programme "BBC Light Programme") aired extracts for
their _Theatre Programme_ from [John
Burrell](/wiki/John_Burrell_\(theatre_director\) "John Burrell \(theatre
director\)")'s [Edinburgh Festival](/wiki/Edinburgh_Festival "Edinburgh
Festival") production, with Patricia Burke and [Trevor
Howard](/wiki/Trevor_Howard "Trevor Howard").[191] In 1954, the full-length
play aired on BBC Home Service, directed by Peter Watts, starring [Mary
Wimbush](/wiki/Mary_Wimbush "Mary Wimbush") and [Joseph
O'Conor](/wiki/Joseph_O%27Conor "Joseph O'Conor"), with [Norman
Shelley](/wiki/Norman_Shelley "Norman Shelley") as Sly.[192] [BBC Radio
4](/wiki/BBC_Radio_4 "BBC Radio 4") aired another full-length broadcast
(without the Induction) in 1973 as part of their _Monday Night Theatre_
series, directed by Ian Cotterell, starring [Fenella
Fielding](/wiki/Fenella_Fielding "Fenella Fielding") and [Paul
Daneman](/wiki/Paul_Daneman "Paul Daneman").[193] In 1989, [BBC Radio
3](/wiki/BBC_Radio_3 "BBC Radio 3") aired the full play, directed by [Jeremy
Mortimer](/wiki/Jeremy_Mortimer "Jeremy Mortimer"), starring [Cheryl
Campbell](/wiki/Cheryl_Campbell "Cheryl Campbell") and [Bob
Peck](/wiki/Bob_Peck "Bob Peck"), with [William Simons](/wiki/William_Simons
"William Simons") as Sly.[194] In 2000, BBC Radio 3 aired another full-length
production (without the Induction) as part of their _Shakespeare for the New
Millennium_ series, directed by Melanie Harris, and starring Ruth Mitchell and
[Gerard McSorley](/wiki/Gerard_McSorley "Gerard McSorley").[195]

In the United States, the first major radio production was in July 1937 on
[NBC Blue Network](/wiki/Blue_Network "Blue Network"), when [John
Barrymore](/wiki/John_Barrymore "John Barrymore") adapted the play into a
forty-five-minute piece, starring [Elaine Barrie](/wiki/Elaine_Barrie "Elaine
Barrie") and Barrymore himself.[196] In August of the same year, [CBS
Radio](/wiki/CBS_Radio "CBS Radio") aired a sixty-minute adaptation directed
by [Brewster Mason](/wiki/Brewster_Mason "Brewster Mason"), starring [Frieda
Inescort](/wiki/Frieda_Inescort "Frieda Inescort") and [Edward G.
Robinson](/wiki/Edward_G._Robinson "Edward G. Robinson"). The adaptation was
written by [Gilbert Seldes](/wiki/Gilbert_Seldes "Gilbert Seldes"), who
employed a narrator (Godfrey Tearle) to fill in gaps in the story, tell the
audience about the clothes worn by the characters and offer opinions as to the
direction of the plot. For example, Act 4, Scene 5 ends with the narrator
musing "We know that Katherina obeys her husband, but has her spirit been
really tamed I wonder?"[189] In 1940, a thirty-minute musical version of the
play written by Joseph Gottlieb and Irvin Graham aired on CBS as part of their
_[Columbia Workshop](/wiki/Columbia_Workshop "Columbia Workshop")_ series,
starring Nan Sunderland and [Carleton Young](/wiki/Carleton_Young "Carleton
Young").[197] In 1941, NBC Blue Network aired a sixty-minute adaptation as
part of their _Great Plays_ series, written by [Ranald
MacDougall](/wiki/Ranald_MacDougall "Ranald MacDougall"), directed by Charles
Warburton, and starring Grace Coppin and [Herbert Rudley](/wiki/Herbert_Rudley
"Herbert Rudley").[198] In 1949, [ABC
Radio](/wiki/Cumulus_Media_Networks#ABC_Radio "Cumulus Media Networks") aired
an adaptation directed by Homer Fickett, starring [Joyce
Redman](/wiki/Joyce_Redman "Joyce Redman") and [Burgess
Meredith](/wiki/Burgess_Meredith "Burgess Meredith").[199] In 1953, NBC
broadcast William Dawkins' production live from the [Oregon Shakespeare
Festival](/wiki/Oregon_Shakespeare_Festival "Oregon Shakespeare Festival").
The cast list for this production has been lost, but it is known to have
featured [George Peppard](/wiki/George_Peppard "George Peppard").[200] In
1960, NBC aired a sixty-minute version adapted by Carl Ritchie from Robert
Loper's stage production for the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, starring Ann
Hackney and Gerard Larson.[201]

  1. **Jump up ^** The term was first used by [Alexander Pope](/wiki/Alexander_Pope "Alexander Pope") in 1725, and has been commonly employed ever since. The _First Folio_ text begins the play with the standard "_Actus primus, Scœna prima_ " heading, and there is no differentiation between the Induction and what is commonly referred to today as Act 1, Scene 1 (Lucentio arriving in Padua).
  2. **Jump up ^** The complete English text of the episode is: "Three merchants, riding home from a fair, fell to talking about the charm of obedience in a wife. At last they laid a wager of a dinner, agreeing that the one whose wife should prove the least obedient should pay for the dinner. Each man was to warn his wife to do whatever he might bid; afterward he was to set a basin before her and bid her leap into it. The first wife insisted on knowing the reason for the command; she received several blows from her husband's fist. The second wife flatly refused to obey; she was thoroughly beaten with a staff. The wife of the third merchant received the same warning as the rest, but the intended trial was postponed until after dinner. During the meal this wife was asked to put salt upon the table. Because of a similarity between the two expressions in French, she understood her husband to command her to leap upon the table. She at once did so, throwing down the meat and drink and breaking the glasses. When she stated the reason for her conduct, the other merchants acknowledged without further trial that they had lost the wager."
  3. **Jump up ^** [Complete Text of _A Merry Jest_](http://ebooks.gutenberg.us/Renascence_Editions/jest.html).
  4. **Jump up ^** From this point forward, _The Taming of a Shrew_ will be referred to as _A Shrew_ ; _The Taming of the Shrew_ as _The Shrew_.
